page.title: 14WOODLAND ECOLOGY
page.content: The Forestry Commission owns 270 acres of woodland in the grid area. There is proportionately more conifer than hardwood. Bere Forest contains beech, oak, birch, ash and sweet chestnut and an indicator of ancient woodland - the small leafed lime. About 40 acres is privately owned and Huntbourn Wood (30 acres) has a replanting programme which increases its hardwood content from a quarter to a third. Felling is in progress at Clays Copse and some good quality softwood harvested. Most birds associated with woodlands are found here blackcaps, gold crests, chiff-chaffs, willow warblers, green spotted woodpeckers, nightingales, grasshopper warblers,roding woodcocks, nightjars & tawny owls. Barn owls are now scarce. Bluebells growing under the beech trees are a joy in May and there are several varieties of fungi.
